Hybrid Index Insurance is a type of agricultural insurance that combines the features of Weather Index Insurance (WII) and Area Yield Index Insurance (YII) to provide comprehensive coverage for farmers.  It leverages the strengths of both approaches, offering more complete protection against a wider range of perils.
Weather Index Insurance (WII) triggers payouts based on pre-defined weather parameters, such as rainfall or temperature, measured at weather stations.  If these parameters fall outside the established thresholds for a specific location and period, a payout is automatically triggered.  This approach offers quick payouts, as the weather data is readily available, and eliminates the need for costly and time-consuming individual farm assessments.  However, WII has limitations.  Localized weather variations can lead to basis risk, meaning that a farmer might experience losses even if the weather index at the nearest station doesn't trigger a payout.  Conversely, a payout might occur even if the farmer doesn't experience a loss.
Area Yield Index Insurance (YII) addresses some of the limitations of WII. It uses the average yield of a defined geographical area (an agro-ecological zone or AEZ) as the basis for payouts.  At the end of the growing season, trained enumerators assess the average yield in each AEZ. If the average yield falls below a pre-determined trigger level, all insured farmers within that zone receive a payout. This approach reduces basis risk compared to WII, as it considers the actual yield experienced by farmers in a given area. However, YII payouts are typically slower than WII, as they require post-harvest yield assessments.
Hybrid Index Insurance combines the rapid payout mechanism of WII with the more accurate yield-based assessment of YII. Farmers receive an initial, quicker payout based on weather index data, providing immediate funds for replanting or addressing other urgent needs. This helps alleviate the immediate financial strain caused by adverse weather events. A second, more comprehensive payout is then made based on the area yield index at the end of the season. This second payout accounts for the overall impact of various perils on crop yields, including not only drought and excessive rainfall but also pests, diseases, and other factors not captured by the weather index.
This dual-pronged approach offers several advantages. The initial weather-index-based payout provides timely financial relief, while the subsequent yield-based payout ensures that farmers receive adequate compensation for their actual losses. This comprehensive coverage protects farmers from a wider range of risks compared to either WII or YII alone.  The hybrid approach also aims to minimize basis risk by incorporating both weather data and actual yield measurements.

Index-Based Livestock Insurance (IBLI) is a novel insurance program designed to protect livestock keepers in drought-prone arid and semi-arid lands from climate-related losses.  It offers a safety net against the devastating impacts of drought, a recurring challenge that significantly threatens the livelihoods of pastoralist communities.
Unlike traditional livestock insurance, which relies on individual animal assessments, IBLI uses an index – in this case, vegetation cover – as a proxy for livestock mortality. Satellite imagery and proprietary algorithms estimate the availability of grazing resources.  When vegetation cover falls below a pre-defined threshold, triggering the index, insured pastoralists automatically receive payouts. This innovative approach bypasses the costly and logistically challenging process of verifying individual animal deaths, making it a more efficient and cost-effective solution for pastoralists in remote areas.
IBLI's innovative use of technology extends beyond satellite imagery.  The program leverages mobile technology for customer enrollment, policy communication, premium payments, and payout disbursement.  In Kenya, for instance, the program integrates with M-PESA, a popular mobile money transfer service, enabling seamless and secure transactions for pastoralists, many of whom have limited access to traditional banking services.  This mobile integration further enhances the accessibility and efficiency of the program.
The International Livestock Research Institute (ILRI) played a crucial role in the development and implementation of IBLI.  Initially piloted in northern Kenya in 2010 with funding from the USAID BASIS Research Program, the project has demonstrably improved the resilience of pastoralist communities.  ILRI continues to provide technical expertise and support to scale up the program to other regions and countries.  According to ILRI research, IBLI has helped pastoralists avoid destitution during drought periods, enabling them to maintain their herds and livelihoods.
The prospective users of IBLI are pastoralists and livestock keepers in arid and semi-arid regions, particularly those vulnerable to the impacts of drought.  These communities heavily rely on livestock for their livelihoods, and drought-induced livestock mortality can have devastating economic and social consequences.  IBLI provides a much-needed safety net, enabling these communities to better manage the risks associated with drought and build resilience against future climate shocks.
The primary function of IBLI is to provide financial protection against livestock losses due to drought.  By receiving timely payouts when drought conditions prevail, pastoralists can purchase fodder, access veterinary services, and take other measures to protect their herds.  This proactive approach helps prevent widespread livestock deaths and mitigates the economic hardships associated with drought.  The program's success in Kenya has led to its expansion into Ethiopia, and it is currently being considered in several other East African countries.
The readiness and adoption levels of IBLI are promising. However, challenges remain, including ensuring affordability for pastoralists, addressing basis risk (the risk that the index does not accurately reflect actual losses), and building trust in the insurance mechanism.
IBLI exemplifies the potential of innovative insurance mechanisms to address the growing challenges of climate change.  By combining satellite technology, mobile banking, and index-based insurance principles, IBLI offers a practical and effective solution for protecting vulnerable pastoralist communities and enhancing their resilience in the face of climate-related risks. The innovative core of IBLI lies in its use of satellite-derived Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) data to determine payout triggers.  NDVI measures the "greenness" of vegetation, providing an objective and readily available indicator of pasture health. This index-based approach circumvents the challenges associated with traditional livestock insurance, which often relies on costly and time-consuming on-the-ground assessments of livestock losses.  These traditional methods can be impractical in remote pastoralist areas and often result in delayed payouts, hindering herders' ability to respond effectively to drought conditions.

They can also cover the costs of transporting livestock to areas with better grazing conditions or enable herders to strategically sell some animals, reducing herd size and relieving pressure on limited resources. This proactive approach helps prevent widespread livestock deaths and preserves the core breeding herd, allowing herders to recover more quickly once the drought subsides. long_description:
Integrated Value-Chain Management (IVCM) is a holistic approach to managing all aspects of a company's operations, from raw material sourcing to finished product delivery.  It breaks down traditional organizational silos, connecting different divisions and functions to create a unified and transparent view of the entire business. This integration enables advanced analytics, planning, and management tools that facilitate a comprehensive understanding of how different Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) interact and influence each other.
A core benefit of IVCM is enhanced traceability.  By meticulously linking operational data across the value chain, businesses can trace a product's journey from its origin to the consumer. For example, in the food industry, a packaged product could be traced back through processing, packaging, distribution, farming practices, and even down to the specific feed and breed of livestock. This granular level of detail empowers businesses to analyze the impact of various factors on product quality, cost, and efficiency.
IVCM leverages technology to connect different parts of the value chain. Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) systems play a crucial role in this integration by providing a central platform for managing various business processes, including finance, human resources, supply chain, and customer relationship management.  These systems collect and store data from across the organization, allowing for a comprehensive view of operations.  Furthermore, IVCM utilizes data analytics and visualization tools to analyze the vast amounts of data generated across the value chain.  This enables businesses to identify trends, patterns, and insights that can inform decision-making and improve operational efficiency.  For example, analyzing data on production costs, transportation times, and customer demand can help optimize inventory levels and reduce waste.
The prospective users of IVCM span across various industries and encompass a range of stakeholders within an organization.  From small businesses to large multinational corporations, any entity seeking to improve operational efficiency, enhance transparency, and gain a deeper understanding of their value chain can benefit from IVCM.  Within an organization, potential users include:
* **Executives and Senior Management:** IVCM provides a comprehensive overview of the business, allowing leaders to make informed strategic decisions based on real-time data and insights.
* **Operations Managers:** IVCM empowers operations managers to monitor performance, identify bottlenecks, and optimize processes across the value chain.
* **Supply Chain Managers:** Enhanced traceability and data analytics enable supply chain managers to improve supplier relationships, manage inventory effectively, and reduce logistics costs.
* **Marketing and Sales Teams:** By understanding customer preferences and market trends, marketing and sales teams can tailor their strategies and improve customer satisfaction.
IVCM represents a significant advancement over traditional, fragmented approaches to value chain management.  By breaking down silos and connecting different parts of the business, IVCM allows for a holistic view of operations, enabling greater efficiency, transparency, and control. This ultimately leads to improved decision-making, increased profitability, and enhanced competitiveness.
The readiness and adoption levels of IVCM vary across industries and organizations.  While some large corporations have implemented sophisticated IVCM systems, many businesses are still in the early stages of adoption.  The increasing availability of affordable technology solutions and the growing recognition of the benefits of IVCM are driving further adoption. As technology continues to evolve, IVCM is expected to become increasingly sophisticated and integrated into the core operations of businesses across various sectors. The future of IVCM likely involves further integration with emerging technologies like the Internet of Things (IoT), artificial intelligence (AI), and blockchain.  IoT sensors can provide real-time data on various aspects of the value chain, from raw material tracking to product delivery. AI algorithms can analyze this data to identify patterns, predict future trends, and automate decision-making. Blockchain technology can enhance transparency and security by creating a tamper-proof record of transactions across the value chain. These advancements will further empower businesses to optimize their operations, improve efficiency, and gain a competitive edge in the marketplace.

One of the core innovative aspects of KRES is its use of conversational AI to provide digital advisory services. Farmers can interact with voice bots and chatbots to receive tailored, farm-level advice on topics such as crop management, pest and disease control, and weather forecasts. This approach makes information accessible even to farmers with limited literacy or access to traditional extension services. The conversational AI also facilitates agri-record keeping through a Plan & Activity Tracker, enabling farmers to track expenses, revenues, and ultimately demonstrate creditworthiness.
Data-driven advisory services are another key element of the KRES platform. Leveraging technologies like sensors, satellites, drones, and big data analytics, KRES provides farmers with location-specific agro-climatic and crop-specific information. This precision agriculture approach supports decision-making, maximizes productivity, and helps reduce costs by optimizing input use and minimizing risks.  The platform also integrates weather information, offering regional and localized forecasts, including weather-adaptive and climate-smart advice.
KRES addresses the crucial issue of pest and disease management through digital tools that assist farmers in diagnosing plant diseases and developing treatment strategies.  Farmers can upload pictures of infected plants via a mobile application for diagnosis and receive recommendations. This feature complements national and regional-level pest and disease early warning systems, contributing to proactive and timely interventions.
Beyond advisory and information services, KRES plays a significant role in market linkage.  Instead of operating as a marketplace itself, KRES adopts a "Smart Digital Agent" approach. This involves connecting farmers with buyers and input suppliers through a network of Rural Agri Entrepreneurs who act as liaisons. This approach facilitates access to markets and inputs, contributing to improved livelihoods for farmers. The network also includes both private and non-private sector partners to strengthen the market linkages.
KRES further supports farmers by developing financial solutions.  Currently under development, these solutions are designed to provide liquidity financing tailored to different farmer segments.  The inclusion of financial services recognizes the critical role of access to capital in adopting improved agricultural practices and scaling production.
The KRES network is accessible through various channels, including smartphones and basic phones, catering to different levels of technological access. With 250 smartphone users and 2,800 basic phone users, the platform demonstrates its reach and adaptability to the context of smallholder agriculture. The use of USSD technology ensures access to services even for farmers with limited internet connectivity.
Initially launched under the Mavo Diami project in Angola, KRES has expanded to operate in Mozambique, demonstrating its scalability and potential for wider adoption. The innovative use of conversational AI, remote sensing, and geodata makes these services accessible to a wider range of farmers, contributing to agricultural transformation in the target regions. It primarily targets users with limited or no access to formal banking institutions, providing financial inclusion to millions across Africa.
M-PESA leverages the widespread availability of mobile phones, even in areas with limited banking infrastructure, to offer a convenient and secure alternative to cash transactions. Users can interact with the service through SMS messages, a mobile app, or a network of authorized agents located throughout the service area.
M-PESA operates on a simple and accessible model. Users register for an account with an authorized M-PESA agent, providing identification. They then deposit cash into their M-PESA accounts through the agent network, converting physical currency into electronic money stored on their mobile phones.  To send money, users enter the recipient's phone number and the amount to be transferred through their mobile device. The recipient, also an M-PESA user, receives a notification and can withdraw the funds as cash from any M-PESA agent outlet.  The system uses a secure platform and PIN codes to ensure transaction security.
The innovative aspects of M-PESA are numerous. Firstly, its branchless banking model bypasses the need for physical bank branches, reaching underserved populations in remote areas. Secondly, its user-friendliness, requiring only basic mobile phone literacy, broadens accessibility to financial services.  Thirdly, its secure platform builds trust and mitigates risks associated with handling cash. By offering a readily accessible and affordable alternative, M-PESA promotes financial inclusion and empowers these underserved communities to participate in the formal economy.
M-PESA serves multiple functions. Primarily, it facilitates person-to-person money transfers, enabling quick and easy remittance of funds domestically and internationally. It also serves as a platform for making payments for goods and services, both online and offline, reducing reliance on cash.  Furthermore, M-PESA provides access to micro-loans and savings products, fostering entrepreneurship and financial planning for its user base.  Additionally, it simplifies salary payments for businesses, reducing administrative costs and ensuring secure and timely disbursement of wages.
M-PESA was launched in 2007 and has achieved widespread adoption across Africa, with operations in Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda, Mozambique, Democratic Republic of Congo, Lesotho, and Ghana. National Plant Health Inspectorate Services Portal (NaPHIS Portal) is a web-based system implemented by the Government of Eswatini's National Plant Health Inspectorate Services (NaPHIS).  It aims to safeguard plant resources from pests and diseases, ensure food security, and facilitate the safe trade of plant products.
NaPHIS's core responsibility is to protect Eswatini's plant resources.  This includes preventing the introduction and spread of plant pests and promoting effective control measures.  Furthermore, NaPHIS plays a critical role in facilitating the safe trade of plants and plant products, adhering to the International Plant Protection Convention (IPPC) standards. The European Union funds this crucial work.
The NaPHIS Portal offers four main services:
1. **Information System and Policy Analysis:** This service likely provides stakeholders with access to relevant information, data, and analysis to support informed decision-making in plant health management and policy development.  This could include pest distribution maps, risk assessments, and regulatory updates.
2. **Pest Risk Analysis (PRA) and Permits:**  This service encompasses the assessment of potential risks posed by specific pests and the issuance of necessary permits for importing, re-exporting, and transporting plant products.  This ensures that imported goods meet phytosanitary requirements and minimizes the risk of introducing new pests.  Phytosanitary certificates are also issued through this service, certifying that plants and plant products are free from specific pests and diseases.
3. **Pest Surveillance, Quarantine, and Diagnostics (SQ&D):**  This service focuses on monitoring and detecting plant pests and diseases within Eswatini.  It includes surveillance activities, quarantine measures to isolate infected plants, and diagnostic services to identify pests and diseases accurately. This proactive approach helps to prevent outbreaks and protect the country's agricultural sector.
4. **Regional Coordination and Inspectorate:** This component facilitates collaboration and information sharing with neighboring countries and regional organizations.  It ensures a coordinated approach to plant health management across the region and strengthens efforts to prevent the spread of pests and diseases across borders.
Launched in 2020 as an agricultural value-added service (Agri-VAS), the NaPHIS Portal has seen significant adoption.  With 600 registered users and 300 active users, the platform streamlines the application and issuance of phytosanitary certificates, permits for regulated plants, plant products, soil, and biological articles.  It also incorporates a traceability system for payments, ensuring transparency and accountability.
The NaPHIS Portal significantly benefits both individuals and businesses involved in the plant trade. Users can conveniently apply for and receive necessary documents online, saving time and travel costs. The platform's accessibility across various devices, including smartphones, tablets, desktops, and laptops, further enhances its usability.  The system comprises two modules: one for applicants (users) and one for government regulators, facilitating seamless communication and processing.  The transition to a digital platform has drastically reduced turnaround times from days or weeks to mere minutes. This efficiency gain benefits both clients and the government, leading to cost savings.  Moreover, NaPHIS has successfully transitioned from paper-based to digitized records, improving record-keeping and information management.
NaPHIS facilitates access to markets by providing the required certification and phytosanitary clearance for agricultural produce.  This reduces the cost of doing business for farmers, simplifies the process of selling produce within Eswatini and neighboring countries, and enhances the government's records of export and import information.  The platform also contributes to improved tracking of pest and disease outbreaks, which is vital for protecting Eswatini’s agricultural production systems.
Developed through donor and central government funding, the NaPHIS Portal will continue to rely on these subsidies in the near future. Its development involved extensive consultations with government entities, commercial companies, entrepreneurs, and social enterprises, adhering to digital design principles. The service operates on a public goods business model, requiring some degree of public subsidy for sustainability.
Challenges faced by NaPHIS include limited digital literacy among some users, inadequate mobile coverage and internet access across the country due to electricity and power supply issues, and the high cost of mobile data.  NaPHIS also provides pest and disease management information, weather information, and produce certification for trade.  It addresses knowledge gaps, combats low productivity, and improves the quality of produce for trade. While the project has demonstrated success on a small scale, expanding its reach and overcoming these challenges will be crucial for maximizing its impact on Eswatini's agricultural sector.

Nilebot is a real-time water quality monitoring and alarming system designed specifically for aquaculture, developed by Conative Labs.  It offers a comprehensive solution for fish farmers of all scales, from small to large operations, by providing continuous monitoring of crucial water parameters and delivering timely alerts in case of deviations from optimal levels.  Currently operating in eight countries, Nilebot aims to address the critical need for efficient, user-friendly, and affordable water quality management in aquaculture.
Nilebot's core functionality lies in its ability to monitor a range of key water quality indicators vital for fish health and growth.  These parameters include:
*   **Dissolved Oxygen (DO):**  Maintaining adequate DO levels is essential for fish respiration and overall well-being.  Low DO can lead to stress, disease, and even mortality.
*   **pH:**  The pH level measures the acidity or alkalinity of the water.  Fish thrive within a specific pH range, and deviations can negatively impact their physiological processes.
*   **Total Dissolved Solids (TDS):**  TDS represents the total concentration of dissolved substances in the water. High TDS can indicate pollution or other imbalances that can harm fish.
*   **Temperature:**  Water temperature directly influences fish metabolism and immune function.  Maintaining optimal temperature ranges is critical for optimal growth and disease resistance.
*   **Salinity:**  For marine or brackish water aquaculture, monitoring salinity is essential for maintaining the proper osmotic balance for the fish species being cultivated.
*   **Electrical Conductivity (EC):**  EC measures the water's ability to conduct electricity, providing insights into the concentration of dissolved ions.  It is closely related to TDS and can be an indicator of water quality changes.
*   **Oxygen Saturation:** This parameter measures the amount of oxygen dissolved in the water relative to the maximum amount the water can hold at a given temperature and pressure.
The data collected by Nilebot's sensors is transmitted wirelessly and accessible through a user-friendly web application. This allows fish farm managers to remotely monitor water conditions in real-time, from anywhere with an internet connection.  The system also features a color-coded alert system within the application, providing a visual indication of potential issues.  Furthermore, in the event of critical deviations from pre-set thresholds, Nilebot sends SMS alerts directly to the fish farmer's mobile phone, enabling immediate intervention to mitigate potential problems.
One of Nilebot's key advantages is its adaptability to diverse aquaculture environments. The system is designed to function effectively in both freshwater and marine fish farms and boasts flexible installation capabilities. Notably, Nilebot can operate independently of existing electrical infrastructure, making it suitable for off-grid or remote locations. This feature significantly expands its potential reach and applicability, particularly in developing countries or areas with limited access to power grids.
Nilebot represents a significant innovation in aquaculture management by addressing the crucial need for affordable and accessible water quality monitoring. Traditional water quality monitoring methods often involve manual sampling and laboratory analysis, which are time-consuming, expensive, and may not provide timely insights into rapidly changing water conditions. Nilebot's real-time monitoring and alert system allows for proactive management, enabling fish farmers to address potential issues before they escalate and impact fish health or production.  
The system's ease of use and affordability make it accessible to a wider range of fish farmers, including small-scale operators who may not have the resources for complex or expensive monitoring equipment.  By empowering farmers with real-time data and timely alerts, Nilebot promotes better water quality management practices, contributing to improved fish health, increased productivity, and more sustainable aquaculture operations. Participatory Integrated Climate Services for Agriculture (PICSA) is a participatory approach that supports climate-smart agricultural planning and decision-making. PICSA emphasizes collaboration between agricultural extension staff, meteorological agencies, NGOs, and most importantly, farmers themselves.
The core of PICSA lies in its participatory nature. Agricultural extension staff facilitate workshops with groups of farmers before the start of the growing season. These workshops begin with an analysis of historical climate data relevant to the specific location. This data helps farmers understand long-term climate trends and variability in their area, providing a foundation for informed decision-making.  Farmers are actively involved in interpreting this data using visual aids and participatory tools.
Following the historical analysis, farmers work together to develop and select crop, livestock, and livelihood options best suited to their individual circumstances and risk tolerance.  This process recognizes that farmers have diverse resources, priorities, and constraints.  The participatory approach ensures that the chosen strategies are realistic, locally appropriate, and tailored to the specific needs of each farmer. long_description:
Precision Farming
Precision Farming can generally be defined as the summary of technologies that enable farmers to perform site specific crop management. Based on data collected from within his crops the management of inputs can be optimized for maximising returns while minimizing inputs.
Using a so-called Decision Support System (DSS) the farm manager will be able to determine accurate spray timing based on Disease Models, perform a protective irrigation based on timely Frost Warnings, and determine harvesting dates and insect development based on Growing Degree Days. But such site-specific action requires accurate and site specific data, delivered in near-real time to the farmer's desk. Adcon Telemetry has the perfect solution, field proven with 25 years of experience.

long_description:
RAPID INCLUSIVITY ASSESSMENT FOR DIGITAL AGRICULTURE SERVICES
The Rapid Inclusivity Assessment (RIA) helps researchers and practitioners create digital agriculture innovations that are inclusive of marginalized farmers. The tool guides the research team through a systematic, critical reflection of the potential risks of (gendered) exclusion in their future digital agriculture service. RIA should be used during early design stages: once there is a concrete idea for a digital service, but before actual software development and implementation. In a half-day workshop, the team identifies challenges likely faced by illiterate, poor, remote, or otherwise digitally excluded target users of their digital service. For every identified risk of exclusion, the team is then urged to come up with ideas for improving their design idea - towards a more inclusive digital service.

Crucially, the Observatory offers detailed grain quality profiles for over 200 rice varieties released in Latin America. short_description: Smart Irrigation Controller is a precision irrigation solution. It uses soil moisture sensors and a dual-node strategy to automate drip irrigation. long_description:
Sasya Systems' Smart Irrigation Controller is a precision irrigation solution that utilizes soil moisture sensors to automate the irrigation process. It maintains soil moisture levels within an optimal range, between the wilting point (WP) and field capacity (FP), by employing a dual-node strategy to control the on/off cycles of drip irrigation. This automated system results in significant water and fertilizer savings, reduced labor costs, and increased crop yields.
The system's core functionality revolves around its network of soil moisture sensors. These sensors continuously monitor the soil's water content, translating this data into pF values (a measure of soil water tension).  This pF value is then compared to pre-set thresholds representing the WP and FP.  If the pF value falls below the WP, indicating insufficient soil moisture, the controller activates the drip irrigation system. Conversely, if the pF value exceeds the FP, indicating waterlogged soil, the controller shuts off the irrigation. This dual-node approach ensures that the soil moisture remains within the ideal range for optimal plant growth, avoiding both water stress and overwatering.
This precise control over irrigation significantly reduces water waste compared to traditional irrigation methods.  Overwatering is a major contributor to water loss and nutrient runoff, both environmentally damaging and economically inefficient. Sasya Systems' controller addresses this by only delivering water when and where it's needed, minimizing unnecessary water consumption.  Furthermore, the precise delivery of water and nutrients reduces the need for excessive fertilizer application, contributing to environmental sustainability and reducing input costs for farmers.
The benefits of automated irrigation extend to labor savings.  Manual irrigation is a time-consuming and labor-intensive process, requiring significant human intervention.  Sasya Systems' solution automates this process, freeing up valuable farm labor for other essential tasks. This automation not only saves time and money but also increases the efficiency of farm operations.
Increased crop yields are another key advantage of the Sasya Systems Smart Irrigation Controller.  By maintaining optimal soil moisture conditions, the system supports healthy plant growth and maximizes crop production.  Consistent moisture availability minimizes stress on plants, leading to increased yields and improved crop quality.  This translates to higher profitability for farmers.
The prospective users of the Sasya Systems Smart Irrigation Controller are primarily farmers and agricultural businesses involved in cultivating crops requiring drip irrigation.  The system is particularly well-suited for larger farms or operations where manual irrigation is impractical or inefficient.  The system's scalability allows it to be implemented on farms of varying sizes, making it adaptable to diverse agricultural contexts.
Regarding readiness and adoption levels, Sasya Systems' website suggests a commercially available and deployed product. While precise market penetration data is not readily available on their site, the existence of the website and the product description indicates a certain level of market adoption.  The innovative aspects of the system, such as the dual-node control strategy and the focus on precise soil moisture monitoring, suggest a technologically advanced approach to irrigation management, placing it at the forefront of modern precision agriculture technologies. long_description:
SBC4D services for Agriculture Digital Transformation

The core of the platform is a farmer digital profiles platform to manage farmers and different modules on top it. Some modules are generic (surveys, alerts,…), and some are service specific (business matching module to manage selling and buying of commodities). Each module has an operator interface (web interface) and a customer interface. The customer interface implements different channels such as Web, mobile app, voice, SMS, WhatsApp, email or USSD interface. Existing modules include :
A Q&A/Extension service Module: This module allows the management of support to farmers. Farmers can ask questions through different interfaces (web/SMS/IVR) and get answers. The answers are then stored and serve as a growing knowledge base, as well as a tool to detect specific trends, like the appearance of specific diseases. This module is deployed in Fiji
A Radio module: This module allows the integration of community radio on the platform. Lots of rural community radio stations today do not have internet connectivity or computers. This module allows the generation and transfer of radio broadcast containing specific farmer offer automatically to community radios that have only basic phones. These radio stations can then broadcast this information live, without the need to transfer a physical media (cd, mp3, tape) to the station.  Associated to this module, we also offer a radio station selection tool that shows the geographical reach and population reach of each radio station based on the radio station equipment (size of the antenna, power of the equipment…). This module is deployed in Mali and Senegal.
A mobile payment module: To ensure sustainability, it is essential to enable payments of services. This module allows the management of mobile payments such as MPesa. this module is deployed in Kenya.A market information module: This module allows the collection of market price information (using smartphone) and their dissemination to farmers. This module is deployed in Fiji and Bhutan.
A Poll module: This module allows the organisations of polls to query members of the CRM on specific questions. This module is deployed in Fiji using SMS.
An Alert module: This module allows the broadcast of messages to members of the CRM. This module is deployed in Fiji using SMS and in Mali using voices (Tabale).
A mapping module: This module allows the capture of gps coordinates (or the geocoding of address information) and the use of GIS system (google map, Open street map) to implement map-based application.
A traceability module: This module provide a centralized traceability platform that can be adapted to any value chain.

long_description:
SeedAssure® is a precision agriculture platform designed to improve the quality and performance evaluation of hybrid seeds. It achieves this through a combination of drone-based data acquisition and agronomist validation, providing seed companies with detailed phenotypical data for each seed variety.
SeedAssure® leverages unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs or drones) to conduct routine surveys of seed trial plots. These drones capture high-resolution imagery and data covering eight critical parameters that influence seed performance. This data is then rigorously validated by experienced agronomists on the ground, ensuring accuracy and reliability. The system compiles this plot-specific data into a timeline-centric database. This database facilitates comparative analyses of different seed varieties across the trial period, providing a comprehensive understanding of their performance under various conditions. The result is a faster and more accurate data collection process compared to traditional methods, eliminating the time and resource constraints of manual field surveys.
The platform's innovative aspect lies in its integrated approach, combining automated data collection with expert human validation. The use of drones significantly accelerates the data gathering process, enabling a more efficient and cost-effective evaluation of seed varieties. The comprehensive database allows for in-depth analysis and comparison of multiple varieties, providing valuable insights for seed companies to optimize breeding programs and improve seed quality. The timeline-centric approach allows for tracking of performance changes throughout the growing season. This contrasts with traditional methods that might only involve measurements at a few set points in time.
The primary prospective users of SeedAssure® are seed companies involved in the development and testing of hybrid seeds. By providing accurate, timely, and comprehensive data on seed performance, SeedAssure® empowers these companies to make informed decisions about which varieties to release to the market. This, in turn, enhances the overall quality of seeds available to farmers, potentially leading to improved crop yields and greater food security.
The functionality of SeedAssure® centers around its ability to monitor and analyze the phenotypical performance of seeds during field trials. The platform’s use cases include accelerating the seed breeding cycle, facilitating informed decision-making about seed variety selection, improving overall seed quality, and enabling more efficient resource allocation for seed companies.
Determining the precise readiness and adoption levels of SeedAssure® requires more information than provided in the given text and linked website. While the technology appears functional and ready for deployment, detailed adoption statistics are not available in publicly accessible sources. However, the fact that the platform is actively advertised and described online suggests that it is either currently being used or is being actively promoted for adoption by seed companies in the market. The technology's efficiency and its potential to streamline seed development make it a compelling solution for a sector focused on improving agricultural output and food security. Its success will depend upon factors like ease of use, integration with existing systems within seed companies, and the continued accuracy and reliability of the data produced by the platform's combined drone and agronomist approach.

Seracell app
SeraCell is a general smart greenhouse solution with smart algorithms, sensors and early warning systems. Wireless and long battery life sensors, sim card, electricity, installation etc. It is very portable and easy to use without requiring It prevents the farmers from going to the greenhouse for frost monitoring during the night, thanks to the temperature-humidity sensor, when the temperature-humidity in the greenhouse reaches the determined threshold values, it notifies the farmer by phone call, SMS and notification methods. It enables the irrigation, fertilization and ventilation systems to be controlled via the mobile application through the sensors in the greenhouse. It also provides suggestions for automatic fertilization, automatic agricultural prescription and automatic disease detection by monitoring values ​​such as soil and air parameters in the greenhouse through sensors. In addition, it provides the health map of the plants in the greenhouse through special cameras. Thus, by detecting the disease on time and recommending the necessary irrigation and fertilization, the cost is reduced, the loss of productivity is prevented and less chemical pollution of the soil is ensured.

long_description:
SHERPA
SHERPA from Blue North Sustainability is a specialised consulting company supporting businesses in the agriculture and food sectors in proactive clarification, development and implementation of sustainability strategies. SHERPA was launched in 2019 and expertly guides and supports businesses on the challenging & complex journey to achieve true and lasting resilience, viability & sustainability. It is operating in Malawi, South Africa and Zambia. Developed by Blue North Sustainability, SHERPA is an integrated on-line management system specifically designed to support & empower business owners, managers and management-teams within agricultural supply-chains, in the development and implementation of proactive, relevant and impactful sustainability strategies for their businesses. It has 52 active users and 305 registered users providing them with Smart advisory: Data-driven advisory based on tailored, farm-level agro-climatic and crop-specific information to support decision making, maximise productivity and reduce costs. Technologies such as sensors, satellites and drones, as well as big data analytics and AI, underpin many of these services., Record keeping: Digital tools that enable farmers to keep detailed records of livestock, including health and feeding data, to help mitigate diseases and avoid missed conceptions. Record keeping tools are also used to keep details of input usage, procurement, cost and revenue and sales records., Information for farms to develop, manage, measure and report a sustainability strategy for their business. SHERPA is designed to enable farmers to take full ownership of the sustainability strategies for their farms, to be in a proactive position in relation to market access requirements and to be able to comprehensively report to their stakeholders. Sherpa is a bottom-up approach and an alternative to the prescriptive "top down" approaches most often used. It puts the control of the sustainability agenda in the hands of the farmer/business management. It covers all aspects of sustainability in a holistic and integrated way, allowing the business to "see", measure and improve the whole system towards greater resilience and viability. The innovation helps build greater resilience and viability and uses computers, landlines, a website, GeoData and cloud-based databases. The advisory addresses a knowledge gap and helping farmers through reporting on multiple prescriptive standards. They have been challenged by digital literacy limitations, access to device, data collection and farmer uptake and behaviour change as well as lack of mobile coverage. They facilitate planning, on-farm production, post-harvest processing and access to markets. They are scaling towards replicating this in other countries, have funded themselves using their own resources and charge individual subscription fees, business subscription fees and an aggregated reporting service vis MS PowerBi over and above SHERPA licenses. They have not taken specific actions for inclusivity. They have worked with Hydrologic based in the Netherlands that also uses ICT solutions to ensure water systems are more weather resistant and climate adaptive. They have also worked with Pixofarm that have developed an App based system to monitor accurate yields on farms. They use noise resistant image processing, machine learning for forecasting and AI for enabling accurate fruit analysis.

long_description:
Skudu digital agronomist
This is an innovation implemented in Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa and Zimbabwe. Skudu Exact launched in 2019 provides smart advisory: Data-driven advisory based on tailored, farm-level agro-climatic and crop specific information to support decision making, maximise productivity and reduce costs. It addresses planning, inputs and on-farm production. Technologies such as sensors, satellites and drones, as well as big data analytics and AI, underpin many of these services. It enables farmers and agronomists to effortlessly automate and expedite plant nutrition guidelines for multiple blocks and fields and product guidelines are issued specific to crop growth state and ordering and application for soil correction. Skudu's algorithm generates the requirement for lime, gypsum, fertiliser and foliar feed specific to the crop, growth stage and region based on provided soil and leaf sample analyses. They have 400 registered users and 50 active users. Their challenges include bridging time and technical capacity to generate plant nutrition guidance (content). They have also had constraints on farmer uptake and technical usability of the platform. They are transitioning to scale, have been funded by technology investors and charge business subscription and transaction fees.

long_description:
Smart Brooder
Smart Brooder is your digital mother hen. It constitutes 3 – 5 sensors that are spread inside the brooding space, at the height of chicks, to measure the temperature and humidity that chicks are feeling. This information is sent to a small analogue computer. This computer is programmed to determine the age of the chicks and regulates the conditions in the brooding space to meet the chicks’ requirements at that specific age, constantly adjusting to maintain the best conditions. Currently, the device is able to control infrared lamps and infrared chicken gas heaters for heating requirements.
The device relays information to the farmer through Short Message Service (SMS) whenever it receives a request from the farmer or when there is a condition it cannot rectify.

SmartSeeds Information services for vegetable farmers in Indonesia
SmartSeeds are information services improving the production, income and food security of vegetable farmers in Indonesia.
SMARTseeds will implement a financially sustainable information service that supports 100.000 vegetable farmers to increase their production, income, food security and reduces the inputs of water, fertilizer and pesticides. Weather, advisory and market information services will be provided to smallholder farmers. Various other B2B services will generate additional revenues such that subscription fees for smallholder farmers can be kept affordable. The services can easily be extended for other types of crops and/or implemented to other regions in Indonesia. The changing climate gives farmer's difficulties in making and consistently using a crop plan. Information on weather forecast and water availability will help farmers adopt a more accurate crop calendar to mitigate the pests and plant diseases related to weather. Information on soil nutrient, estimated price of commodities, and new technology on fertilizer and seeds will help farmers choose the most profitable commodities to be produced. SMARTseeds services will be distributed via interactive SMS and mobile phone app. Farmers will be informed through SMS as well as personal advice via extension officers from EWINDO. B2B clients, like input suppliers, vegetable buyers, farmers groups, farmers with smartphones, financing institutions, government and NGOs can access SMARTseeds via a mobile phone app or through the web portal using a computer or laptop with internet access

Soil Test Methods app
Soil testing is central to the nutrient management planning for economically profitable and ecologically sustainable crop production. Of late, it has assumed unprecedented importance in view of the growing awareness about soil health card in Indian agriculture. Indiscriminate use of fertilizers based on their blanket recommendations or without knowing the native availability of plant nutrients in soil is of little importance in modern agriculture which not only aims at improving crop productivity but also at maintaining the fertility status of soil for sustained crop production. Further, reliability of the ‘soil test based nutrient recommendations’ depends largely on precision of soil testing, which necessitates proper understanding and knowledge of soil testing methods for different soil parameters commonly used in preparation of soil health card and making nutrient recommendations. In order to acquaint you (students, researchers and soil test personnel) with the procedures of soil testing, we present here an android based mobile application “Soil Test Methods” and hope it serves as an instant soil testing guide to you.

long_description:
Solar-Powered Irrigation Systems for Agriculture
Solar-powered irrigation systems represent a sustainable solution for agricultural water management, combining solar energy technology with efficient water distribution methods. These systems, such as those offered by Agritech Group, integrate solar pumps with drip irrigation technology to provide farmers with a cost-effective and environmentally friendly irrigation solution.
The core components of these systems include:
- Solar panels that convert sunlight into electrical energy
- Solar-powered water pumps
- Drip irrigation infrastructure
- Control systems for water distribution
- Storage tanks (in some configurations)
The primary innovation lies in the combination of renewable energy and water efficiency. Solar pumps eliminate the need for grid electricity or diesel fuel, making the system both environmentally sustainable and economically viable for farmers in remote locations. The drip irrigation component ensures precise water delivery directly to plant roots, minimizing water waste through evaporation or runoff.
These systems are particularly beneficial for:
- Small and medium-scale farmers
- Agricultural operations in remote areas without reliable grid power
- Regions with water scarcity issues
- Farmers looking to reduce operational costs
- Sustainable agriculture practitioners
The scalability of these systems is demonstrated through various kit options designed for different farm sizes:
- 1 hectare systems for small-scale farmers
- 5 hectare systems for medium-sized operations
- 10 hectare systems for larger farms
- 20 hectare systems for commercial agricultural operations
The advantages of solar-powered irrigation systems include:
- Zero fuel costs after initial installation
- Minimal maintenance requirements
- Reduced carbon footprint
- Improved water use efficiency
- Independence from grid infrastructure
- Lower long-term operational costs
According to research by the International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA), solar-powered irrigation systems can reduce water usage by up to 40-80% compared to conventional irrigation methods, while eliminating energy costs that typically represent 20-25% of total operational costs in traditional irrigation systems.
The technology has seen increasing adoption globally, particularly in regions with high solar irradiation and agricultural activity. Countries like India, Morocco, and Kenya have implemented successful programs to promote the adoption of solar irrigation systems among farmers. Market research indicates that the global solar-powered irrigation systems market is expected to grow at a CAGR of around 15% between 2021 and 2026.
The readiness level of this technology is high, with proven implementations across various geographical and agricultural contexts. The systems are commercially available and have demonstrated reliability in different climate conditions. The main barrier to adoption is often the initial investment cost, though this is frequently offset by governmental subsidies and the long-term savings in operational costs.
The drip irrigation component of these systems typically achieves water efficiency rates of 90% or higher, compared to 60-70% for sprinkler systems and 40-50% for surface irrigation methods. This efficiency is crucial in regions facing water scarcity or drought conditions.
Modern solar irrigation systems often incorporate smart technology features such as:
- Remote monitoring capabilities
- Automated scheduling
- Soil moisture sensors
- Weather-based irrigation adjustments
- Mobile app control interfaces
These additional features help farmers optimize water usage and system performance while providing real-time data for better decision-making in crop management.

Sudhokko
The tool is primarily intended for use among livestock service providers (LSPs), with the support of livestock officers, while making farmers more confident in the services being provided. The software features on the free smartphone app include: schedule creating, details regarding providing medical care, medicine selection based on disease/symptoms, accounts keeping, calculating transportation cost, call records, reminder. It also contains videos that LSPs can share with farmers. After a visit from a participating livestock service provider, farmers receive a text message with a visit summary, details on treatments and prescriptions, and have the chance to provide feedback on services. The app has been tested with 100-120 LSPs since October 2019. Companies can promote their products on the app. The data generated by the LSPs in using the app is curated into a web-based Market Intelligence Platform with livestock pharma companies and research organizations as the end users. The platform will avail them information like disease pattern, medicine usage pattern of LSPs in different types of diseases, usage of their own brands of products as well as other brands by LSPs etc. An added Breed Identification and Cattle Registry feature helps the artificial insemination (AI) technician to identify the breed of a particular cow, by matching the types and percentages of exotic breed charecteristic present in that cow, in order to make optimum recommendation for AI selection.

long_description:
SUM Africa
Transforming Africa's food system through low-cost insurance products
Agriculture is a major driver of African economies. In recent years, climate change is increasingly affecting crop production in Sub-Saharan Africa, negatively impacting farmers livelihoods and hampering economy growth. The G4AW SUM Africa project is addressing this challenge by using satellite-based weather data to create a low-cost insurance product for smallholders in Mali and Uganda. With this insurance, farmers have a greater chance to obtain the credit they need to increase crop production and improve their livelihoods.
Agricultural index insurance products are linked to an index, such as temperature, rainfall, crop yield or evapotranspiration, rather than actual loss. Daily information from (meteorological) satellites, provide timely, independent and continuous monitoring of climatic conditions and drought for crop growth. This information is used by insurance companies for risk assessment, insurance pricing, and for pay-out calculation. Because insurance companies no longer need to visit the farmer to assess their loss and determine payout, transaction costs are much lower.

Aleph Farms' cultivated meat production system is a cellular agriculture technology that aims to enhance sustainability, food security, and animal welfare within the food production industry.  It achieves this by diversifying the supply and decentralizing the production of high-quality animal proteins and fats.  This method serves as a supplementary approach to traditional animal agriculture practices, rather than a complete replacement.
Aleph Farms' core innovation lies in its ability to cultivate meat directly from animal cells, bypassing the need for raising and slaughtering animals.  The process begins with taking a small biopsy sample of animal cells. These cells are then placed in a bioreactor, a controlled environment that provides nutrients and growth factors necessary for cell proliferation and differentiation.  The cells multiply and self-assemble into muscle tissues, mimicking the natural growth process of animal muscle.  The resulting tissue is then processed and structured to create a meat product resembling conventional meat in terms of texture, taste, and nutritional profile.  While the specific details of Aleph Farms' proprietary bioreactor technology and cell-culture medium are not publicly available, the company's website and press releases highlight their focus on creating a sustainable and scalable production system.
The prospective users of Aleph Farms' cultivated meat are diverse and include consumers seeking sustainable and ethically produced meat alternatives, food companies looking to diversify their product portfolios, and governments interested in enhancing food security and promoting animal welfare.  The technology addresses the growing concerns about the environmental impact of traditional livestock farming, including greenhouse gas emissions, land usage, and water consumption.  By reducing the reliance on conventional animal agriculture, Aleph Farms' cultivated meat offers a potential solution to mitigating these environmental challenges.  Furthermore, cultivated meat production can be less susceptible to animal diseases and biosecurity threats than traditional farming, leading to a more stable and reliable supply chain.
Currently, Aleph Farms’ cultivated meat is not yet widely available to consumers on a large scale. The readiness level of Aleph Farms' cultivated meat technology can be characterized as being in the late-stage development phase, with the transition to commercialization representing a critical next step.  The adoption level is currently limited to specific pilot programs and research collaborations; however, with further regulatory approvals and successful scaling up, wide-spread adoption is projected in the coming years.  Aleph Farms' technology demonstrates a promising path towards a more sustainable and ethical meat production system, although significant hurdles remain in terms of achieving cost-effectiveness and scalability for mass market penetration.

long_description:
TAHMO projects
TAHMO is a public-private consortium (Dutch/USA). TAHMO installs a network of automatic weather stations across Africa. TAHMO leverages the mobile telecommunications plat­form, crowdsourced technology that is durable and cost-effective (e.g. partnered with METER Group in the co-design of robust weather station), and partnerships with local schools to achieve its goals. Most TAHMO stations are in schools (from primary to university), where a teacher “hosts” the station, and gets free access to TAHMO teaching materials and data from their station. The first station was installed in 2012 and by the end of 2019 500 weather stations are operational in 21 countries. The projection for 2020 is to have 800 stations running and reporting. TAHMO also works on developing better weather stations appropriate for Africa, educating youth on climate change and supporting local entrepreneurs to cover running costs of weather stations. A key partnership is with the USAID, SIDA, the World Bank, and Rockefeller Foundation funded Global Resilience Partnership. TAHMO also works with other development partners and businesses including agreement with IBM / Weather Underground with a major investment to add 333 stations. Data is free for NMHSs, researchers, and the public. To ensure long-term financial sustainability, TAHMO provides data services to commercial users. Clearly, value chains run from raw data to actionable information. Willingness to pay increases exponentially along that chain. For this reason, TAHMO has become part of a network of entities that bridge the gap between weather station and information market.
